Physical and biological range uncertainties limit the clinical potential of Proton Beam Therapy (PBT).
body_text.section: (Received November 18, 2019)

body_text.text: In these proceedings, we report on two research projects, which we are conducting in parallel and which both tackle the problem of range uncertainties.
body_text.section: (Received November 18, 2019)

body_text.text: One aims at developing software tools and the other at developing detector instrumentation.
body_text.section: (Received November 18, 2019)

body_text.text: Regarding the first, we report on our development and pre-clinical application of a GPU-accelerated Monte Carlo (MC) simulation toolkit Fred.
body_text.section: (Received November 18, 2019)

body_text.text: Concerning the letter, we report on our investigations of plastic-scintillator-based PET detectors for particle therapy delivery monitoring.
body_text.section: (Received November 18, 2019)

body_text.text: We study the feasibility of Jagiellonian-PET detector technology for proton beam therapy range monitoring by means of MC simulations of the β + activity induced in a phantom-by-proton beams and present preliminary results of PET image reconstruction.
body_text.section: (Received November 18, 2019)

body_text.text: Using a GPU-accelerated Monte Carlo simulation toolkit Fred and plastic-scintillator-based PET detectors, we aim at improving the patient treatment quality with protons.

body_text.text: Introduction

The increasing numbers of proton facilities and successful proton treatments [1] indicate that the relevance of Proton Beam Therapy (PBT) as a technique for tumor radiation therapy is rapidly growing.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Kraków proton facility has been in clinical operation since October 2016 and more than 10 patients a day are currently treated.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Range uncertainties, i.e. uncertainty of the distance that protons travel inside patient body, currently represent one of the biggest caveats for the exploitation of the full potential of proton therapy treatments [2].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The protonbeams range is particularly affected by biological and physical uncertainties in a heterogeneous patient body.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Therefore, to assure target coverage, medical physicists currently apply up to about 1 cm safety margins around the tumor volume, which lead to the unwanted irradiation of the healthy tissues surrounding the tumor [2].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The biological dose, D RBE expressed in Gy(RBE), delivered to the patient is the actual quality of clinical interest.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: It is calculated as D RBE = D × RBE, where D is the physical dose expressed in Gy and RBE is the Relative Biological Effectiveness.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: By definition, in conventional therapy with photons RBE = 1.0, therefore, physical and biological doses are equal and correlated with clinical response.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Protons have an increased biological effectiveness compared to photons, i.e. RBE is larger than one.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Currently, in clinical routine, the RBE of protons is assumed to be constant and equal to 1.1 [3].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This convention neglects complex, often nonlinear dependency of the RBE on such parameters as penetration depth, Linear Energy Transfer (LET), dose, fractionation scheme, tissue type and endpoint, cell cycle phase or oxygenation level.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: These dependencies might affect the effective proton range, i.e., introduce biological range uncertainty and thus affect the dose to the surrounding tissue and Organs at Risk (OAR).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Modification of proton physical dose by RBE, which is an uncertain weighting factor, makes the correlation of proton biological dose and clinical effect of tumor irradiation uncertain, and unification of clinical studies comparing the effectiveness of different radiation modalities challenging.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: An improvement resulting from the correctly applying radiobiological assumptions in PBT could be achieved only under the condition that the physical dose is accurately delivered to the patient.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In fact, physical range uncertainties, occurring due to patient mispositioning or Computed Tomography (CT) scanner calibration introducing Hounsfield Unit (HU) to stopping power conversion, could cause differences between treatment plan and treatment delivery.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Monte Carlo simulations and range monitoring methods are essential in PBT to guarantee that the physical dose is accurately delivered and, therefore, to reduce the biological and physical range uncertainties in a patient body.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: along with activities of our group (dark gray/orange color) aiming to improve PBT quality.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: We incorporate advanced nuclear physics computational and experimental methods to predict physical and biological dose in patient more accurately and to monitor proton beam range in patient by means of PET imaging.

body_text.text: Monte Carlo simulations to address physical and biological range uncertainties of proton beams

It is recognized that Monte Carlo (MC) methods can offer improved dose calculation accuracy in heterogeneous media and, therefore, predict more accurately therapeutic dose distributions in patients compared to the analytical algorithms that are typically employed in the Treatment Planning Systems (TPS) used in clinical routine [2].
body_text.section: Monte Carlo simulations to address physical and biological range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: Nowadays, the use of a variable RBE is being discussed among the PBT scientific community.
body_text.section: Monte Carlo simulations to address physical and biological range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: We perform biological dose calculations with variable RBE and investigate biological range uncertainties by means of MC simulations of patient CT images exploiting the MC dose calculation tool Fred [4,5].
body_text.section: Monte Carlo simulations to address physical and biological range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: Fred offers a unique combination of features: accuracy of an MC code including biological dose computation, flexibility of a research tool, and high-dose calculation speed due to GPU-acceleration.
body_text.section: Monte Carlo simulations to address physical and biological range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: These characteristics are impossible to achieve with the currently available commercial TPS and general purpose MC codes such as Geant4/FLUKA [6,7].
body_text.section: Monte Carlo simulations to address physical and biological range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: We have successfully implemented in Fred the proton beam model used clinically for patient treatment in the Kraków facility.
body_text.section: Monte Carlo simulations to address physical and biological range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: The Integrated Depth Dose (IDD) profiles of single proton pencil beams in water simulated with Fred MC code for different energies are in excellent agreement with the IDDs obtained during the commissioning measurements (see Fig. 2, left), showing differences of less than 2%.
body_text.section: Monte Carlo simulations to address physical and biological range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: The emittance model, describing lateral beam propagation in air, was implemented in Fred, in accordance with the clinical system.
body_text.section: Monte Carlo simulations to address physical and biological range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: The longitudinal and lateral pencil beam shapes are modeled in Fred MC with a submillimeter precision.
body_text.section: Monte Carlo simulations to address physical and biological range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: We validated the beam model experimentally using the transversal patient treatment plan verification measurements.
body_text.section: Monte Carlo simulations to address physical and biological range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: Such measurements are routinely performed by medical physicists for treatment plan quality assurance with an array of 1020 ionization chambers (MatriXX IBA) placed in a water phantom.
body_text.section: Monte Carlo simulations to address physical and biological range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: A transversal dose plane extracted from Fred MC and the dose distribution measured with the MatriXX detector at the same depth in water, as well as the Gamma Index (GI) map obtained from GI test are presented in Fig. 2.
body_text.section: Monte Carlo simulations to address physical and biological range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: The GI passing rate (3%/2 mm criteria) greater than 98% was obtained for 182 dose planes measurements for 10 patients.
body_text.section: Monte Carlo simulations to address physical and biological range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: Based on these results, we can assure that dose distributions of clinical treatment plans can be recalculated accurately.
body_text.section: Monte Carlo simulations to address physical and biological range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: We are currently performing treatment planning studies to quantify the biological range uncertainties exploring various biological models with variable RBE and clinical data of patients treated in Kraków.
body_text.section: Monte Carlo simulations to address physical and biological range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: An example of a selected Head and Neck (H&N) patient is presented in Fig. 3, where the radiobiological dose distributions computed with constant and variable RBE using Fred as well as corresponding Dose Volume Histograms (DVHs) are shown.
body_text.section: Monte Carlo simulations to address physical and biological range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: The MC calculation time for this case was about 10 min (9 × 10 8 primary protons, 2 × 10 6 p + s tracking rate).
body_text.section: Monte Carlo simulations to address physical and biological range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: The mean dose to Planning Target Volume (PTV), calculated with Fred using variable RBE model proposed by Carabe [8], is increased with respect to the clinically applied constant RBE = 1.1 assumption of about 3 Gy(RBE), whereas the maximum dose to the brain stem OAR increases by about 4 Gy(RBE).
body_text.section: Monte Carlo simulations to address physical and biological range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: Our results show that incorporation of the variable RBE model in patient dose calculation increases the dose in PTV and OAR with respect to constant RBE assumption.
body_text.section: Monte Carlo simulations to address physical and biological range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: This is especially important when OARs are very close to or overlap with the PTV as it occurs frequently in H&N patients.
body_text.section: Monte Carlo simulations to address physical and biological range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: Considering variable RBE hypothesis in the proton therapy clinic could be essential as the increased biological dose deposited to OARs that exceeds clinical dose constraints can be potentially associated with the increased normal tissue complication probability and, therefore, an increased risk of necrosis or secondary cancer.
body_text.section: Monte Carlo simulations to address physical and biological range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: The use of the fast MC dose computation tool Fred for physical and biological dose recalculation of patient treatment plans (retrospectively and prospectively) can provide additional clinical information for medical physicists and medical doctors, and can potentially prevent inaccuracies in patient treatment.

body_text.text: J-PET detector to address physical range uncertainties of proton beams
The proton interactions with patient tissues allow range monitoring during or just after the treatment detecting emitted secondary radiation.
body_text.section: J-PET detector to address physical range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: Tracking of prompt-gamma, PET-gamma, and secondary protons and neutrons are examples [9][10][11].
body_text.section: J-PET detector to address physical range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: Prototype systems for prompt-gamma and PET-gamma range monitoring were tested clinically and obtained satisfying precision of Bragg peak position monitoring on-line in the PBT treatment room [12][13][14].
body_text.section: J-PET detector to address physical range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: At the Jagiellonian University in Kraków, a novel solution for diagnostic PET imaging, Jagiellonian-PET (J-PET) is being developed [15][16][17][18].
body_text.section: J-PET detector to address physical range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: A single detection unit of the J-PET scanner [19] consists of a 50 cm long and 6 × 24 mm 2 intersection size scintillator strip.
body_text.section: J-PET detector to address physical range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: The light pulses produced in the strip by 511 keV back-to-back photons propagate to its edges, where they are converted into electrical signals by photomultipliers (PMT).
body_text.section: J-PET detector to address physical range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: The interaction position of the photon with the detector is estimated from the time difference between the PMT signals located at the ends of the strip.
body_text.section: J-PET detector to address physical range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: A J-PET module consists of 13 scintillator strips read-out through a single front-end electronics and an FPGA-based DAQ system.
body_text.section: J-PET detector to address physical range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: A modular, lightweight and portable design of J-PET enables flexibility in detector configuration and easy installation.
body_text.section: J-PET detector to address physical range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: Increasing the number of J-PET detector layers, increases the detection efficiency of the system.
body_text.section: J-PET detector to address physical range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: We performed comprehensive MC simulations using the GATE toolkit [20] and reconstructions of 3D β + activity distributions using the CASTOR software [21].
body_text.section: J-PET detector to address physical range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: The aim was to characterize the sensitivity of the J-PET for proton beam range detection.
body_text.section: J-PET detector to address physical range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: We investigated single and multi-layer cylindrical and dual-head configurations of the J-PET modules that can be possibly applied for the in-room range monitoring.
body_text.section: J-PET detector to address physical range uncertainties of proton beams

body_text.text: The list-mode TOF-MLEM reconstruction (5 iterations with 500 ps TOF resolution without regularization) takes into account random events, scatter, attenuation and normalization corrections.

body_text.text: Eventually, the reconstructed PET-activity profiles can be correlated with the position of dose distal fall-off (Fig. 4, right) and used for proton beam range monitoring.

body_text.text: Summary

Within the research projects conducted in the Institute of Nuclear Physics Polish Academy of Sciences in Kraków, we investigate physical and biological range uncertainties of proton beams through positron emission tomography (PET) based solutions and Monte Carlo (MC) simulations.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: Taking advantage of the Fred accuracy and time performance possible due to the GPU acceleration, we aim at improving quality assurance and treatment planing in Kraków PBT facility.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: A Monte Carlo study of J-PET detector feasibility performed in the frame of the project suggests that this technique might be considered as a novel proton beam therapy range monitoring approach.
